thread.title: Rogers: Gloom, lack of progress dangerous for U.S. and Jurgen Klinsmann
thread.title_full: Rogers: Gloom, lack of progress dangerous for U.S. and Jurgen Klinsmann

title: Rogers: Gloom, lack of progress dangerous for U.S. and Jurgen Klinsmann
text:
Jurgen Klinsmann (Photo: Kevork Djansezian, Getty Images)
2 CONNECT 12 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE PASADENA, Calif. – The Confederations Cup is not, as FIFA would like you to believe, a monumental soccer event of global importance.
Missing out on it then, which the United States has somehow managed to do thanks to a combination of missteps and misfortunes culminating in Saturday’s 3-2 extra-time defeat to Mexico, should perhaps not be seen as a catastrophe.
Yet there was a sense of gloom at the Rose Bowl in the aftermath of an entertaining night with an unsatisfactory American conclusion that ran far deeper than the basic dejection of having lost to a local enemy via a crushing late winner.
And gloom, for a head coach like Jurgen Klinsmann, is the greatest poison of all, more deadly than anger, more dangerous than despair or fear or even apathy.
Klinsmann, four years into the job and widely hailed as the savior of soccer in this country as he arrived riding a blueprint of progression and positivity, is struggling to convince anyone that he has achieved much of either.
USA TODAY
Mexico defeats U.S. in CONCACAF Cup, advances to Confederations Cup
The much-vaunted tactical policy that was supposed to get the U.S. playing free-flowing, all-action soccer that would take the offense to the opposition has been tried, tested, and on this evidence discarded, at least for now.
As for progression, what progression? The team reached the last 16 at the last World Cup, but though Klinsmann set relatively modest goals for the calendar year of 2015, his team has fallen short of them.
He wanted victory in the Gold Cup over the summer, but didn’t get it, falling to Jamaica in the semifinals. Failing that, he wanted qualification for the 2017 Confederations Cup to come through the second chance saloon of Saturday’s CONCACAF Cup showdown with Mexico, but that fell apart too.
As much as anything, he wanted the nation’s Olympic squad to book its place in Rio, yet that is also in great peril, following a defeat to Honduras that makes qualification a long shot, at best.
Klinsmann is a positive man with a glass half-full outlook, but he is getting close to running on empty in the public goodwill stakes. For while his team responded twice against Mexico, bouncing back to equalize after falling behind early in regulation and in the opening minutes of extra time, they never truly looked like winning the game, or grasping full control of it.
USA TODAY
Mexico fans outnumber U.S. fans at CONCACAF Cup in Pasadena
And not just does Klinsmann no longer have the total belief of the American soccer public, he doesn’t have a Plan A anymore either. That floated away into the Southern California sky the moment Paul Aguilar slammed home his superb volleyed winning goal and sent the Rose Bowl erupting into a sea of green joy.
Klinsmann wanted tournament soccer to prepare his charges for the experience of a World Cup. That meant the Gold Cup this year, the Copa America featuring some of the best teams from South America coming to U.S. soil next summer, and the Confederations Cup the year after that.
Well, that didn’t work out so well. The Gold Cup was a disappointing farce, the Copa America may not even happen due to FIFA’s corruption scandal and it will be Mexico heading to Russia for the Confederations Cup instead.
With the qualifying campaign for the 2018 World Cup due to start next month, Klinsmann looks like a coach short on ideas. He wouldn’t admit as much of course, because, as an eternal optimist, he doesn’t believe it is true.
Such a cheery outlook is admirable and commendable and you would hope it can rub off on some of his demoralized players following the heartbreaking nature of Aguilar’s 118th minute strike.
Yet it is hard to imagine followers of the national team will share his bright outlook right now, through the haze of this defeat. They see only a cup that is empty and a trophy that passed into Mexican hands.
